name: Inaugural Meetup
description:
For our first meetup, we'll be meeting at Shopify's Toronto office. Come for Android tech talks, food and drinks, and chat with other people interested in Android. 

>> Talks

• Up and Back Again, by Marvin Bernal, TWG

This talk will delve into details of Android App Design, especially how it differs from other fruity platforms. We will go over some Android terminology such as the Navigation Bar, Action Bar and Action Overflow, the concepts of Activities and Intents, how to design for an infinite amount of screens and some delightful concepts of Material Design.

Marvin Bernal is an Android Developer currently at The Working Group. He has worked on Android for 3 years in the industry working on a variety of applications including The Globe and Mail tablet and phone applications as well as designing medical applications at UHN, Toronto General Hospital. In addition he has a huge interest in UX design and is fascinated about the design of every day things.

• Fast List Scrolling with ORMLite, by Eric Fung, Shopify
"Buttery-smooth" list scrolling is an important part of ensuring a good user experience. But achieving this when rendering data from multiple database tables can be tricky. This talk will describe the steps I took to debug the performance issues and arrive at a solution using ORMLite.

Eric currently works on Android apps at Shopify. He has worked previously at Zynga and Five Mobile building mobile games and apps, and spent the first part of his career developing cryptographic toolkits and applications at BlackBerry and Certicom.


>> Thanks

Thanks to Shopify for hosting, and providing refreshments.

name: Android Tech Talks
description:
Our next meetup will be hosted at theScore. Come for Android tech talks, food and drinks, and chat with other people interested in Android. 

>> Talks

• Download This!  How to Promote Your Android App, by Phil Shadlyn

So you’ve made a killer app, now how do you get people to download it?  You could always resort to begging or bribery, but luckily Google has provided a few ways to make this task a little easier (and cheaper!).  Join us as we talk about some proven and successful ways to promote your app, including a few that aren’t just limited to Android.  Whether you’re an indie dev or your company needs help getting the word about its latest product, you’ll come away with some helpful tips.

About Phil:
I love Android even more than baseball.
I head up Android development for IDEAL LIFE, a leader in remote medical monitoring and mobile healthcare.  I’ve also done Android development for Triplify, an Australian-based startup which tells you what’s going on wherever you are. I started working with Android during the Froyo days and have never looked back.

• The Basics of Custom UI, by Mark Iantorno

Creating a memorable experience for users by including custom UI components is what separates your app from the others on the Play Store. More importantly, especially in settings like healthcare, good UI/UX is what encourages patients to continue using the apps you make. In this presentation, I’ll provide a brief introduction into the basics of custom drawing on Android, and explain the most common operations available to you.

About Mark:
I’ve been in the IT field as both a developer and project manager for almost a decade, working on everything from mobile games to cell phone network billing software. Over the last two and a half years, I’ve had the privilege of working as an Android developer at the Centre For Global eHealth Innovation, a nonprofit research organization part of University Health Network. The software we develop helps improve the quality of life for patients dealing with chronic conditions, and assists clinical care staff in doing their jobs. 

I’m incredibly proud of the work we do everyday.

>> Thanks

Thanks to theScore for hosting us and providing refreshments.

name: Talks of Various Kinds
description:
This month, we're going to try something a bit different, and hear shorter talks from more speakers. With a mix of styles and subjects, we hope it will be an entertaining evening.

Speakers to include:

• Joseph Wong — Knowledge Portfolios
• Andrew Rodrigues — Converting User Feedback Into User Appreciation
• Eric Fung — PRESTO Lookup: The Untold Story
• Rubin Yoo — RxJava
• Marvin Bernal — Living Life Fabulously

Thanks to TWG for hosting and help with planning.

name: Better App Architecture + Firebase
description:
We're back with two technical talks for this month, at Shopify's office.

◙ Upgrade to Architect: Skills to scale your impact, Yervant Kulbashian

The popular image of a ‘Software Architect’ carries connotations of respect, expertise, and sometimes pompousness. But in practice, regular programming and software architecture are not that different. ‘Architecture’ is just how you manage code for the long term.

If you’re soon to lead a large Android project (or already are), I’ll present a few tips to help you create a project that survives scaling-up and its inevitable onslaught of feature requests. We’ll delve into S.O.L.I.D. principles and how they apply to Android, using a live code demo.

Although some Android experience is useful for getting the most out of this talk, most of it is applicable to any programmer that wants to code at scale, in any language.

◙ Firebase Notifications, Eric Fung

With only a minimum of coding, Firebase provides your Android app with simple push notifications and collects analytics to measure user engagement. However, if you need to customize the notifications or their behaviour, you need to implement everything yourself.

For a recent Android news app I developed, I wanted to use push messaging to inform users when new articles were published. This talk will describe how I used Firebase tools (Notifications, Cloud Messaging, Remote Config and Analytics) to implement custom notifications and analytics to track their performance.

This is appropriate for Android developers who are interested in implementing push notifications with Firebase to re-engage their users. No prior experience with Firebase is needed.

Eric began his career in the embedded world, writing cryptographic toolkits. Since 2010, he has been working in mobile, and is currently employed as an Android developer at Shopify. He has built a backend to deliver notifications to multiple mobile platforms, and has tinkered with Android cloud messaging technologies from C2DM onwards.

name: Two Talks: Compound Components + AOSP
description:
COMPOUND COMPONENTS, Michelle Mendoza

Have you ever had two layout components or view groups that you found you were using repeatedly? Ever wish you could combine two or more components and refer to it by one name? Enter Compound Components! App views and custom layouts are created easily using this concept - once you’ve learned how to do this, you’ll be compelled to figure out a way to turn those UI designs into compound components. We'll look at some real world uses such as form buttons, loading/error pages and password fields. Previous knowledge on layout inflation and component instantiation is suggested.

At Nudge Rewards, Michelle heads up development on the Android app using tips and tricks to save time while building a stable app used by both customer-facing employees and management employees alike.

Previously on BlackBerry's Developer Relations team, Michelle has helped indie and enterprise developers build their apps to platform standards through tech talks and code samples.

---

THE INS AND OUTS OF AOSP, Stefan Mitev

A talk that will cover both application and platform/ROM development. We will start with the fundamentals of the Android OS, go through the basics of Android application development, then explain everything you need to know from modifying the platform to flashing it on a real device and will finish with some tips and tricks.

Suitable for both beginner and advanced users.

Stefan Mitev is a young software engineer with over 13 years of programming experience with mobile, desktop, web and recently with embedded development. Originally from Bulgaria, but studied and lived for quite a while in The Netherlands where he also worked in a mobile app agency. Last year Stefan moved to Canada to work on a mobile project at a company in the automotive industry. Loves Android and Windsurfing.

name: Android Tech Talk
description:
Thanks to Pivotal Labs, who has been kind enough to host us and sponsor our November meetup!

KOTLIN, Adam Erb

Kotlin is a static-typed, functional / object-oriented programming language that targets Android, the JVM, and Web. Since hitting the 1.0 milestone early this year it has gained a lot of attention, specifically in the Android community, for its combination of modern features, high performance, and small runtime. Kotlin's emphasis on interoperability with Java has also made it an attractive option for developers maintaining large Java code-bases.I have been using Kotlin at work for the last 6-months to add new-features and refactor parts of an existing Android app. For this talk I will give an overview of Kotlin's features and syntax, and describe my experience of learning and working with the language. This talk is appropriate for anyone interested in learning about Kotlin, and will required no previous knowledge of the language. While I will emphasize programming on Android, it should be applicable to anyone with a Java background.

Adam Erb is a Java and Android developer at EBlock.ca. He grew up in Northern Ontario. He has worked as a professional programmer for the last 5 years in Norway and Toronto. If you buy him a beer he'll tell you all about it.

name: Holiday Social
description:
Hello everyone!

We're thrilled about how well received the Toronto Android Developers Meetup has been this year, and looking forward to continued events in 2017!

Let's end off the year with a social event, by grabbing some food and drinks to usher in the holiday season.

I have booked a space for 20 people, under my name.

Please keep your RSVP updated!

name: First talks of 2017
description:
Grokking Android Studio - Phil Shadlyn

We spend the majority of our coding lives in Android Studio, yet few of us (myself included) know all the tips and tricks to unlock its full potential. Knowing your IDE inside and out can help to level up your productivity, and not to mention make you look really cool to everyone else on your team. Join us as we talk about:

• Simple navigation through the IDE - put down your mouse!

• The basic and more obscure key mappings, which make repetitive tasks a breeze

• Live Templates - what are they, and how can you make your own?

• A few other tips and tricks that will come in handy.

Whether you’re new to Android or a seasoned pro, you will come away having learned something new.

Internet of Things, Android Things, and Other Things - Denys Karpov

Google announced a new platform, Android Things (AT), and this is good news for Android developers. My talk is about what the Interent of Things is, and how and why Google created its own platform. We'll see what AT can and cannot do, сonsider the available development tools, and how to create a new project. We will try to find the differences between the traditional ways of development of embedded systems and AT. In addition, I'll cover AOSP features, Google Weave and other popular protocols and services in this area.

Denys is a software developer who recently migrated to Canada. Prior to that, he worked for Petcube (2014 Europas Award for the Best Hardware Startup). In addition to developing on Android, he is interested in the development of embedded systems.

name: API Talks: Mocking with Retrofit and Swagger, and, GraphQL
description:
18:30 Meet and Greet
19:00 Talks
20:15- More Mingling


Client first APIs with mock data, Retrofit and Swagger, Jeff Corcoran 

GraphQL, Ivan Savytskyi

⬤ Client first APIs with mock data, Retrofit and Swagger, Jeff Corcoran

If you're an independent app developer or part of a small team, you might not always have the luxury of a fully spec'd out project with proper requirements. Some clients lean on "agile" development to justify shifting scope and ask for frequent demos and updates in order to nail down what they really want.

This talk covers a real world example of using mock request JSON data with Retrofit and OkHttp to facilitate API calls easily allowing for any adjustments to changing requirements and scope without having to worry about your backend during the development process.

We'll also discuss fleshing out your mock data with Swagger to seamlessly create an enterprise-level documented API.

This talk is for all levels of Android developer and also briefly mentions integrating with popular libraries Dagger2 and RxJava.

⬤ GraphQL, Ivan Savytskyi

GraphQL is next evolution of REST developed by Facebook, more and more companies are migrating to it. So what options do we have when building Android client connected to GraphQL server? 

During this talk we will discuss:

• Introduction to GraphQL

• GraphQL vs. REST: why it is the next evolution of REST API

• Static schema generated queries vs. runtime queries in GraphQL Android clients

• Overview of existing approaches to create Android GraphQL client

• Apollo GraphQL Client

name: Getting up to speed with Android
description:
This month, two speakers share their stories about getting themselves, and others, up to speed with Android.

● What I learned, learning Android, Smriti Das

So you have a killer idea for an app, and you want to build it for Android?  But there are so many different, online options to choose from, especially for beginners looking to learn Android development… where to start?!

I will help you navigate the complexities of the Android Universe, first through my experience with Udacity’s Android Basics course.  Then, through my experiences with other MOOC’s, such as: Treehouse, Udemy, Coursera, etc. and all along the path, I will share what I learned about learning Android, itself, often the hard way.

● Challenges and lessons from porting a complex iOS app to Android, Mike Dai Wang

“iOS first, Android after” has been a common undertaking for many companies and developers. Without proper preparation however, porting an iOS app to Android can be challenging and result in less than satisfying experience for developers and users.

This talk will detail my recent endeavour in helping a client company with no Android engineers launch their app on a tight deadline. I will explore both technical and non-technical challenges of the project with lessons learned in:

• Defining project scope

• Designing with Material Design vs. existing user tested UI elements

• Setting up efficient yet reliable development and testing process

• Training and helping engineers at different levels to ramp up on Android

• Architecting the app in a clean and modular way

• Making good use of tools and libraries

This presentation is aimed at all levels of Android developers as well as those who would like to explore areas beyond development.

name: May Android Talks
description:
18:30 Mingling

19:00 Talk starts

• Dealing with all your undocumented features - Debugging Android, Mark Iantorno  

Debugging is one of the fundamental skills in software development. Over the past decade, I've had the privilege of training dozens of promising junior developers. However, time and time again, I'm blown away by how little experience they have using the basic debugging tools provided by Google. This presentation aims to address this blind spot by highlighting the principal tools developers have at their disposal to identify and resolve bugs in their code.

name: Two Talks: Video and Security
description:
18:00 Doors open
18:30 Mingle, pizza and drinks
19:00 Talks start

This month, Namrata Bandekar talks about local video processing, and a special guest from Detroit, Godfrey Nolan, talks about Android security from a developer perspective.

Namrata Bandekar, "Video Processing on Android"

An increasing number of social media apps such as Instagram, Snapchat and Messenger are using video features. With modern Android devices having enough processing power to run video processing algorithms locally, there's no need to send videos through expensive internet bandwidth to be processed on the backend. Overlays, transcoding and cropping are just a few of the challenges you face when working with video on-device. In this talk I will go through my experience experimenting with built-in as well as third party libraries for video manipulation on Android. We will look at the benefits of two leading media processing libraries, and how you can leverage them to enhance Android's native MediaCodec API to accomplish these tasks. You will walk away with a head start on how to tackle the most common challenges with videos on Android.

Godfrey Nolan, "Android Security"

This session takes a look at Android security from a developer rather than a hacker's perspective. Using the OWASP Top 10 Mobile risks, we look at how to protect your Android code, how to use secure authentication in your app, how to communicate securely with any backend server and how to safeguard that server against attack. Throughout the session we'll use real world examples from the many audits we've done over the years to show how other developers have tried and sometimes failed to secure their code.

name: Lightning ⚡️ Talks
description:
18:30  Check-in, socializing, food/drink
19:00  Talks start
20:30  Socializing

• Teyvonia T – Developing Computer Vision Applications for Android

• Phil S – Droidcon Boston vs. Chicago Roboto vs. Staying Home: Conference Recaps

• Neal M – App Security - Protecting secrets in Android apps

• Moe A – Merge Layouts

• Jeff C – So you made an app and nobody cares

• Jeff H – Best Practices for Unit Testing

name: Lightning Strikes Twice ⚡️
description:
Schedule

18:30  Check-in, socializing, soft drinks

19:00  Talks start 

20:30  Socializing

Speakers

Joel Ruetas - Google Developers Certification - Associate Android Developer

Steven Zimmerman - An Introduction to Software Licensing, and How to Pick a Software License

Adam Erb - The Joy of Painting with Android Canvas

Nicholas Chum - Overlays: How Themes Work

Zohaib Hussain - Transforming XML+XSLT to HTML on Android

Todd Burgess - How to Dependency Inject a Kitten: An Intro to Dagger 2

Code of Conduct

We've added a Code of Conduct, please read before you RSVP: 

http://bit.ly/2vkYaSo

name: High and Low Level Talks
description:
18:30  Snacks and Socializing
19:00  Talks start
20:30  More socializing

Two talks: one about high-level things (Android Architecture Components) and one about low-level things (Zygote, Binder, Application Framework).

Dario Mungoi - Android Architecture Components: An Intro to Lifecycles 

Historically, understanding the Android lifecycles and how to make an app handle correctly this different states and transitions has been one of the biggest challenges faced by android developers.

Many libraries and solutions have emerged over the years and earlier this year at Google IO 17, Google presented the Architecture Components library to help the developers better architect their android applications and treat the lifecycle as a first class citizen.

In this talk you will learn:

• What is the android architecture components library.

• Use the LiveData to observe data.

• What is a lifecycle owner and how they work.

• Use the ViewModel with LiveData to observe data and retain across configuration changes.

• Build a custom lifecycle aware component.

Djoume Salvetti - Android Application Framework from the Bottom Up

Programming an Android Application is very different from programming a regular Linux app. Why is that? This presentation will go over Zygote, Binder and the Activity Manager to show how those low-level components address critical design constraints of the system (Security, Low Memory, Slow CPU) and shape the Application Framework.

name: Rise and Fall: SQL and React Native
description:
18:30 Doors Open, Chit Chat
19:00 1st talk: SQL on Android: Rise and Shine
~19:45 2nd talk: Why React Native is Not for You
20:30 That's all folks

SQL on Android: Rise and Shine (Eric Fung, Shopify)

Let’s take a stroll through the landscape of databases on Android, and see where we’re headed. We’ll go through examples from a few implementations (Android's own API, ORMLite), then look at the trend of letting SQL emerge from the shadows (SQLDelight, Room).

Why React Native is Not for You (Josh Allen, Connected Lab)

You have read the hype. You have done the tutorial. Now your manager is asking for a critical decision. Is React Native a way to save time and money developing your next app? Come listen to a deep dive into React Native--what makes it tick, how did the geniuses at Facebook make it work--as well as some hard data to help you understand React Native is not the elixir your boss has been hoping for.

name: A Retro Talk
description:
18:30 Doors Open (food and mingling), 19:00 Talk Starts

• A Retro Talk by Adam Pelsoczi 

From inception, Android has been plagued byte obstacles. This talk compiles Java 8/9 APIs backported to Java 6, offering developers, back to Ice Cream Sandwich, more goodies to play with!

name: Holiday Hangout
description:
For our December meetup, we wanted to get the group together for casual drinks and games at The Rec Room! Come out, have a drink with us and enjoy the games with your Android colleagues. If you are playing the games, you'll need to purchase credits, see here for details:
http://www.therecroom.com/toronto-roundhouse/games/video-games

Hope to see you there!
how_to_find_us: The Rec Room, 255 Bremner Blvd, Toronto, ON M5V 3M9

name: Gradle Demystified

venue.name: Connected Lab
venue.address_1: Suite 300, 370 King Street West, Toronto, ON

description:
18:30 Meet and Greet
19:00 Talk starts

Josh Allen, Connected Lab

Have you spent frustrating hours trying to get Gradle to do what should have been a simple task? We are going to deep dive into Gradle to understand how it works and how to decipher its syntax. You will go from copy & pasting answers from Stack Overflow to being the resident expert. Your build process will hum and perform the magical tasks you always dreamed it could do.

name: Technical Talk(s)
description:
18:30 Mingling
19:00 Talk starts

I Wrote an App Using all of the Architecture Components... And Here's How It Turned Out
Phil Shadlyn (@physphil), Shopify

I developed an app from scratch using all of the new Architecture Components – ViewModels and an MVVM architecture, Room to persist all the local data, and LiveData objects to easily and safely update the UI with automatic lifecycle handling. Join us as we discuss in detail what it’s like to use these new Architecture Components in a real world situation – we’ll talk about the problems they solved, the problems they created, and whether or not they’re the right choice for your next project.

name: Introduction & Getting Started with Flutter
description:
18:30 Doors Open, Meet and Greet
19:00 Talk Begins

Flutter is one of the most talked about technologies this year. Flutter is Google’s mobile UI framework for crafting high-quality native interfaces on iOS and Android in record time.

Learn how to design, develop and deploy Flutter apps in this talk!

About the speaker: Faisal Abid (@FaisalAbid) is a Google Developer Expert, Entrepreneur and Engineer. He is a programming language enthusiast and loves solving software engineering challenges across the stack. In his free time, Faisal leads Javascript, Node.js, Dart, or Android workshops and presents at conferences such as OSCON, JFokus, CodeMotion, and FITC.

name: Not the Droid You're Looking For
description:
18:30 Meet and Greet
19:00 Talk Begins

Evading Vulnerability Exploitation Through Secure Android Development

The first commercially-available Android device was released in 2008. Despite its nearly 10-year public lifespan, the OS still poses numerous security challenges. Now, as mobile becomes an increasingly popular platform for consumers, we're faced with the challenge of protecting these consumers from new, quickly evolving threats. We’ll discuss why Android security is so much more challenging for software developers compared to iOS and the web, look at the most common attack vectors for the operating system, and walk through best practices for guarding against them.

About the speaker: Kristina Balaam (@chmodxx_) is an Application Security Engineer with Shopify. She builds web and mobile security tools and helps discover vulnerabilities in the existing platform. Prior to Shopify, Kristina led a team of developers, building web and mobile applications for enterprise and start-up clients. Kristina graduated with a Bachelor of Computer Science from McGill University in 2012.

name: ⚡️Lightning Talks
description:
18:30 Meet and Greet
18:45 Talks begin!

Lightning talks are back by popular demand. We'll hear from many different speakers, on many different topics, but not for too many minutes:

⚡️ Android KTX — Arturo Meijia
⚡️ Not commonly used features of Palette — Jeff Corcoran
⚡️ Secure Storage Paw-blems — Raed Makhlouf
⚡️ Don't Forget About Jank - Steven Zimmerman
⚡️ Developing Augmented Reality Applications — Teyvonia Thomas

name: Lightning Talks, Part 2
description:
18:30 - Doors open
19:00 - Let the sparks fly!

• Adam Erb: I wrote an app without Layouts, Fragments, or Activities
• Barış Emre Efe: Introduction to Instant Apps
• Eric Fung: ML Kit: Hype or Har Gow?

name: ./javac lib && sudo apt-get superpowers
description:
18:30 Doors open, meet and greet
19:00 Talks begin

Building an Android Library
Jigar Brahmbhatt

Given so many android libraries and private SDKs are out there, and devs are building new ones, it's of high importance that we talk about what a solid SDK means, and how to go out building it.

How the Command Line Can Give You Superpowers
Eric Fung

I want to show you how the command line can simplify, and even automate some of the things Android developers need to do. Learning how to use command line tools will give you more ways to get your work done.

Using Mac OS X as the platform, I'll demonstrate real-world examples of how you can generate Java and Kotlin code, edit visual resources, speed up manual testing, enhance pull requests, manipulate JSON files, and more. All from a terminal, without using a GUI!

name: Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?
description:
18:30 Doors open, chit chat
19:00 Talk begins

Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?
Godfrey Nolan, Founder and President of RIIS LLC

This class is a hands-on guide to adding AI to your DJI drone’s mobile app to literally count sheep in a field. We'll walk through the steps on how to 1) use crowdsourcing to gather and label images 2) use TensorFlow to train our data 3) deploy the inference graph in an Android app finally 4) use the DJI mobile SDK to map the flight and process the images to count the sheep.

name: Android Dev Summit Viewing Party in Kitchener
description:
Google invites you to a special & unique viewing party event!

Android Dev Summit is happening on November 7-8, 2018 at the Computer History Museum. Google wants to make this special event more accessible and create a great experience for you. Join the Android Dev Summit viewing party to watch live the summit at the Kitchener Cineplex movie theater on November 7, 2018. You can find the details in the website. Registration, as well as lunch, is free!

https://events.withgoogle.com/android-dev-summit-viewing-parties/

*NOTE: This event is not organized by GDG Toronto Android. Do not RSVP on Meetup. Use the website above!*

name: Android Interviews: Asking the Stuff That Matters
description:
18:30 Doors open
19:00 Talk by Yervant Kulbashian

"Describe what a Content Provider does, then never use one again for the remainder of your career."

Developer interviews are notoriously bad predictors of job performance. Companies regularly employ an ad-hoc cocktail of irrelevant quizzes, burdensome assignments, and inapplicable whiteboard problems to screen potential candidates, hoping to separate the code ninjas from the amateurs.

But how much of this actually works? How well do whiteboard tasks correlate with on-the-job productivity? How can you ensure you don’t reject great candidates based on little more than a - possibly biased - intuition? How can you show declined candidates the path to improvement, and help them to succeed in the future?

“We’ve decided not to go ahead with your application at this time.”
“Why?”
“I don’t know. I’m the hiring manager.”

The goal of this talk is threefold:

• To help you clarify what you are trying to discover from an interview,
• To define best practices that surface promising candidates,
• To leave all candidates feeling fairly treated, regardless of the outcome.

Based on a decade of corporate research, as well as my own, and my peers' experience hiring Android devs across three companies, this talk presents a practical approach to hiring your next Android dev, one that ensures even rejected candidates hold your company in high regard.

name: Productivity Hacks & React Native
description:
18:30 Doors open
19:00 Talks begin

Developing the right things
Asaf Gitai

A short talk from Asaf Gitai, Mobile and Product Manager at Top Hat

Android Productivity Hacks
Rubin Yoo

Building Android apps isn’t just about dealing with Android code. You have to deal with version control, ADB, meetings, and constant reminders.

I will be sharing hacks that have been helping me for years. I will be talking about using Git, shell scripts, Android Studio, and Slack to improve your daily productivity and help you get back to coding faster.

React Native: A Beginner's Journey
Simon Reggiani

React Native and other cross-platform solutions are getting more and more popular. As Android developers, we can either be scared of them or embrace them. In this talk, I'll share my journey from the former to the latter, and what I learnt from it.
